title: 107_hr1181
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is introduced, which includes a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" introduces a tax credit for individuals who pay for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. Married individuals who do not file a joint return and do not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year are subject to special rules under this subsection. An eligible coverage month is defined as a month where the individual is covered by qualified health insurance with premiums paid by the taxpayer. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. The credit is reduced based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. The credit is reduced based on adjusted gross income, which is calculated by subtracting the applicable dollar amount from the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year. Any amount not a multiple of $10 is rounded down. The applicable dollar amount is $60,000 for taxpayers with coverage for more than one individual. Qualified health insurance coverage under this section includes medical care insurance, excluding coverage with mostly excepted benefits. The credit does not apply to subsidized coverage or coverage where less than 50% of the cost is paid by the taxpayer. Marital status is determined according to section 7703. The tax credit for qualified health insurance does not apply to amounts paid under certain government-provided programs, including those listed in the Social Security Act, Title 10, Title 38, and the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Additionally, no credit is allowed if the amount paid for health insurance is used to determine deductions under other sections of the tax code. The tax credit for qualified health insurance does not apply if the amount paid is used to determine deductions under other sections of the tax code. The dollar amounts for the credit are adjusted for inflation annually. The tax credit for qualified health insurance is adjusted annually for inflation. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100, it is rounded down to the nearest multiple of $100. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not double counting the deduction with other medical deductions and not allowing the deduction for self-employment tax purposes. Conforming amendments include adding a new item for the deduction in the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is added to the Internal Revenue Code, with special rules to prevent double counting and exclusion for self-employment tax purposes. The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
